text: Benedict de Spinoza, THE ETHICS
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (Ethica Ordine Geometrico Demonstrata)
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Translated by R. H. M. Elwes
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PART V:  Of the Power of the Understanding, or of Human Freedom
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PREFACE
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: At length I pass to the remaining portion of my Ethics, which is concerned
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: with the way leading to freedom. I shall therefore treat therein of the
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: power of the reason, showing how far the reason can control the emotions,
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and what is the nature of Mental Freedom or Blessedness; we shall then be
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: able to see, how much more powerful the wise man is than the ignorant.
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: It is no part of my design to point out the method and means whereby the
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: understanding may be perfected, nor to show the skill whereby the body may
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be so tended, as to be capable of the due performance of its functions. The
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: latter question lies in the province of Medicine, the former in the province
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of Logic. Here, therefore, I repeat, I shall treat only of the power of the
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind, or of reason; and I shall mainly show the extent and nature of its
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: dominion over the emotions, for their control and moderation. That we do
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not possess absolute dominion over them, I have already shown. Yet the
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Stoics have thought, that the emotions depended absolutely on our will, and
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that we could absolutely govern them. But these philosophers were compelled,
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by the protest of experience, not from their own principles, to confess,
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that no slight practice and zeal is needed to control and moderate them:
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and this someone endeavoured to illustrate by the example (if I remember
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rightly) of two dogs, the one a house-dog and the other a hunting-dog. For
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by long training it could be brought about, that the house-dog should become
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: accustomed to hunt, and the hunting-dog to cease from running after hares.
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: To this opinion Descartes not a little inclines. For he maintained, that the
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: soul or mind is specially united to a particular part of the brain, namely,
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to that part called the pineal gland, by the aid of which the mind is
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: enabled to feel all the movements which are set going in the body, and also
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: external objects, and which the mind by a simple act of volition can put in
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: motion in various ways. He asserted, that this gland is so suspended in the
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: midst of the brain, that it could be moved by the slightest motion of the
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: animal spirits: further, that this gland is suspended in the midst of the
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: brain in as many different manners, as the animal spirits can impinge
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thereon; and, again, that as many different marks are impressed on the said
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: gland, as there are different external objects which impel the animal
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: spirits towards it; whence it follows, that if the will of the soul suspends
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the gland in a position, wherein it has already been suspended once before
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by the animal spirits driven in one way or another, the gland in its turn
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reacts on the said spirits, driving and determining them to the condition
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: wherein they were, when repulsed before by a similar position of the gland.
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: He further asserted, that every act of mental volition is united in nature
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to a certain given motion of the gland. For instance, whenever anyone
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: desires to look at a remote object, the act of volition causes the pupil of
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the eye to dilate, whereas, if the person in question had only thought of
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the dilatation of the pupil, the mere wish to dilate it would not have
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: brought about the result, inasmuch as the motion of the gland, which serves
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to impel the animal spirits towards the optic nerve in a way which would
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: dilate or contract the pupil, is not associated in nature with the wish to
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: dilate or contract the pupil, but with the wish to look at remote or very
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: near objects. Lastly, he maintained that, although every motion of the
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: aforesaid gland seems to have been united by nature to one particular
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thought out of the whole number of our thoughts from the very beginning of
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: our life, yet it can nevertheless become through habituation associated with
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: other thoughts; this he endeavours to prove in the Passions de l'ame, I. 50.
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: He thence concludes, that there is no soul so weak, that it cannot, under
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: proper direction, acquire absolute power over its passions. For passions as
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: defined by him are "perceptions, or feelings, or disturbances of the soul,
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which are referred to the soul as species, and which (mark the expression)
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are produced, preserved, and strengthened through some movement of the
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: spirits." (Passion del l'ame,I.27.) But, seeing that we can join any motion
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the gland, or consequently of the spirits, to any volition, the
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: determination of the will depends entirely on our own powers; if, therefore,
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we determine our will with sure and firm decisions in the direction to which
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we wish our actions to tend, and associate the motions of the passions which
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we wish to acquire with the said decisions, we shall acquire an absolute
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: dominion over our passions. Such is the doctrine of this illustrious
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: philosopher (in so far as I gather it from his own words); it is one
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which, had it been less ingenious, I could hardly believe to have proceeded
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from so great a man. Indeed, I am lost in wonder, that a philosopher, who
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: had stoutly asserted, that he would draw no conclusions which do not follow
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from self-evident premisses, and would affirm nothing which he did not
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: clearly and distinctly perceive, and who had so often taken to task the
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: scholastics for wishing to explain obscurities through occult qualities,
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: could maintain a hypothesis, beside which occult qualities are commonplace.
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: What does he understand, I ask, by the union of the mind and the body? What
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: clear and distinct conception has he got of thought in most intimate union
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: with a certain particle of extended matter? Truly I should like him to
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: explain this union through its proximate cause. What clear and distinct
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conception has he got of thought in most intimate union with a certain
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: particle of extended matter? What clear and distinct conception has he got
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of thought in most intimate union with a certain particle of extended
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: matter? But he had so distinct a conception of mind being distinct from
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: body, that he could not assign any particular cause of the union between the
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: two, or of the mind itself, but was obliged to have recourse to the cause of
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the whole universe, that is to God. Further, I should much like to know,
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: what degree of motion the mind can impart to this pineal gland, and with
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: what force can it hold it suspended? For I am in ignorance, whether this
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: gland can be agitated more slowly or more quickly by the mind than by the
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: animal spirits, and whether the motions of the passions, which we have
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: closely united with firm decisions, cannot be again disjoined therefrom by
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: physical causes; in which case it would follow that, although the mind
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: firmly intended to face a given danger, and had united to this decision the
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: motions of boldness, yet at the sight of the danger the gland might become
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: suspended in a way, which would preclude the mind thinking of anything
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: except running away. In truth, as there is no common standard of volition
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and motion, so is there no comparison possible between the powers of the
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind and the power or strength of the body; consequently the strength of one
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cannot in any wise be determined by the strength of the other. We may also
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: add, that there is no gland discoverable in the midst of the brain, so
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: placed that it can thus easily be set in motion in so many ways, and also
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that all the nerves are not prolonged so far as the cavities of the brain.
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Lastly, I omit all the assertions which he makes concerning the will and its
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: freedom, inasmuch as I have abundantly proved that his premisses are false.
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Therefore, since the power of the mind, as I have shown above, is defined by
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the understanding only, we shall determine solely by the knowledge of the
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind the remedies against the emotions, which I believe all have had
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: experience of, but do not accurately observe or distinctly see, and from the
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: same basis we shall deduce all those conclusions, which have regard to the
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind's blessedness.
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: AXIOMS.
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I. If two contrary actions be started in the same subject, a change must
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessarily take place, either in both, or in one of the two, and continue
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: until they cease to be contrary.
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: II. The power of an effect is defined by the power of its cause, in so far
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as its essence is explained or defined by the essence of its cause. (This
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: axiom is evident from III.vii.)
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROPOSITIONS.
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop.I. Even as thoughts and the ideas of things are arranged
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and associated in the mind, so are the modifications of body or
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the images of things precisely in the same way arranged and
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: associated in the body.
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.- The order and connection of ideas is the same (II:vii.) as the order
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and connection of things, and vice versa the order and connection of things
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is the same (II:vi.Coroll. and II:vii.) as the order and connection of
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ideas. Wherefore, even as the order and connection of ideas in the mind
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: takes place according to the order and association of modifications of the
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: body (II:xviii.), so vice versa (III:ii.) the order and connection of
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: modifications of the body takes place in accordance with the manner, in
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which thoughts and the ideas of things are arranged and associated in the
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind. Q.E.D.
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP.II. If we remove a disturbance of the spirit, or emotion,
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from the thought of an external cause, and unite it to other
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thoughts, then will the love or hatred towards that external cause,
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and also the vacillations of spirit which arise from these
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: emotions, be destroyed.
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.- That, which constitutes the reality of love or hatred, is pleasure
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or pain, accompanied by the idea of an external cause (Def. of the
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Emotions:vi.,&vii.); wherefore, when this cause is removed, the reality of
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: love or hatred is removed with it; therefore these emotions and those
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which arise therefrom are destroyed. Q.E.D.
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop.III. An emotion, which is a passion, ceases to be a
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: passion, as soon as we form a clear and distinct idea thereof.
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.- An emotion, which is a passion, is a confused idea (by the general
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Def. of the Emotions). If, therefore, we form a clear and distinct idea of a
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: given emotion, that idea will only be distinguished from the emotion, in so
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: far as it is referred to the mind only, by reason (II:xxi.,&Note); therefore
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (III:iii.), the emotion will cease to be a passion. Q.E.D.
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary.- An emotion therefore becomes more under our control, and the
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind is less passive in respect to it, in proportion as it is more known to
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: us.
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop.IV. There is no modification of the body, whereof we
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cannot form some clear and distinct conception.
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.- Properties which are common to all things can only be conceived
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: adequately (II:xxxviii.); therefore (II:xii.and Lemma. ii. after II:xiii.)
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: there is no modification of the body, whereof we cannot form some clear and
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: distinct conception. Q.E.D.
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary.- Hence it follows that there is no emotion, whereof we cannot
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: form some clear and distinct conception. For an emotion is the idea of a
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: modification of the body (by the general Def. of the Emotions), and must
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore (by the preceding Prop.) involve some clear and distinct
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conception.
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.- Seeing that there is nothing which is not followed  by an effect
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (I:xxxvi.), and that we clearly and distinctly understand whatever
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: follows from an idea, which in us is adequate (II:xl.), it follows that
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: everyone has the power of clearly and distinctly understanding himself and
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: his emotions, if not absolutely, at any rate in part, and consequently of
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: bringing it about, that he should become less subject to them. To attain
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: this result, therefore, we must chiefly direct our efforts to acquiring, as
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: far as possible, a clear and distinct knowledge of every emotion, in order
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that the mind may thus, through emotion, be determined to think of those
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: things which it clearly and distinctly perceives, and wherein it fully
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: acquiesces: and thus that the emotion itself may be separated from the
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thought of an external cause, and may be associated with true thoughts;
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whence it will come to pass, not only that love, hatred, &c. will be
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: destroyed (V:ii.), but also that the appetites or desires, which are wont to
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: arise from such emotion, will become incapable of being excessive (IV:lxi.).
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: For it must be especially remarked, that the appetite through which a man is
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: said to be active, and that through which he is said to be passive is one
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and the same. For instance, we have shown that human nature is so
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: constituted, that everyone desires his fellow-men to live after his own
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fashion (III:xxxi.Note); in a man, who is not guided by reason, this
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: appetite is a passion which is called ambition, and does not greatly differ
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from pride; whereas in a man, who lives by the dictates of reason, it is an
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: activity or virtue which is called piety (IV:xxxvii.Note.i. and second
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: proof). In like manner all appetites or desires are only passions, in so far
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as they spring from inadequate ideas; the same results are accredited to
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: virtue, when they are aroused or generated by adequate ideas. For all
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: desires, whereby we are determined to any given action, may arise as much
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from adequate as from inadequate ideas (IV:lix.). Than this remedy for the
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: emotions (to return to the point from which I started), which consists in a
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: true knowledge thereof, nothing more excellent, being within our power, can
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be devised. For the mind has no other power save that of thinking and of
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: forming, adequate ideas, as we have shown above (III:iii.).
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop.V. An emotion towards a thing, which we conceive
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: simply, and not as necessary, or as contingent, or as possible, is,
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: other conditions being equal, greater than any other emotion.
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.- An emotion towards a thing, which we conceive to be free, is greater
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: than one towards what we conceive to be necessary (III:xlix.), and,
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consequently, still greater than one towards what we conceive as possible,
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or contingent (IV:xi.). But to conceive a thing as free can be nothing else
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: than to conceive it simply, while we are in ignorance of the causes whereby
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it has been determined to action (II:xxxv.Note); therefore, an emotion
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: towards a thing which we conceive simply is, other conditions being equal,
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: greater than one, which we feel towards what is necessary, possible, or
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: contingent, and, consequently, it is the greatest of all. Q.E.D.
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop.VI. The mind has greater power over the emotions and is
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: less subject thereto, in so far as it understands all things as
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessary.
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.- The mind understands all things to be necessary (I:xxix.) and to be
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: determined to existence and operation by an infinite chain of causes;
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore (by the foregoing Proposition), it thus far brings it about, that
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it is less subject to the emotions arising therefrom, and (III:xlviii.)
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: feels less emotion towards the things themselves. Q.E.D.
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.- The more this knowledge, that things are necessary, is applied to

text: particular things, which we conceive more distinctly and vividly, the
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: greater is the power of the mind over the emotions, as experience also
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: testifies. For we see, that the pain arising from the loss of any good is
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mitigated, as soon as the man who has lost it perceives, that it could not
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by any means have been preserved. So also we see that no one pities an
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: infant, because it cannot speak, walk, or reason, or lastly, because it

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: passes so many years, as it were, in unconsciousness. Whereas, if most
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: people were born full-grown and only one here and there as an infant,
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: everyone would pity the infants; because infancy would not then be looked on
title: Ethics — Part 5

text: as a state natural and necessary, but as a fault or delinquency in Nature;
title: Ethics — Part 5

text: Prop.VII. Emotions which are aroused or spring from reason, if
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we take account of time, are stronger than those, which are
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: attributable to particular objects that we regard as absent.
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.- We do not regard a thing as absent, by reason of the emotion
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: wherewith we conceive it, but by reason of the body, being affected by
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: another emotion excluding the existence of the said thing (II:xvii.).
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Wherefore, the emotion, which is referred to the thing which we regard as
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: absent, is not of a nature to overcome the rest of a man's activities and
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: power (IV:vi.), but is, on the contrary, of a nature to be in some sort
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: controlled by the emotions, which exclude the existence of its external
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cause (IV:ix.). But an emotion which springs from reason is necessarily
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: referred to the common properties of things (see the def. of reason in
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: II:xl.Note.ii.), which we always regard as present (for there can be nothing
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to exclude their present existence), and which we always conceive in the
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: same manner (II:xxxviii.). Wherefore an emotion of this kind always remains
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the same; and consequently (V:Ax.i.) emotions, which are contrary thereto
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and are not kept going by their external causes, will be obliged to adapt
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: themselves to it more and more, until they are no longer contrary to it; to
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: this extent the emotion which springs from reason is more powerful. Q.E.D.
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop.VIII. An emotion is stronger in proportion to the number of
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: simultaneous concurrent causes whereby it is aroused.
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.- Many simultaneous causes are more powerful than a few (III:vii.):
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore (IV:v.), in proportion to the increased number of simultaneous
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: causes whereby it is aroused, an emotion becomes stronger. Q.E.D.
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.- This proposition is also evident from V:Ax.ii.
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop.IX. An emotion, which is attributable to many and diverse
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: causes which the mind regards as simultaneous with the emotion
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: itself, is less hurtful, and we are less subject thereto and less
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: affected towards each of its causes, than if it were a different and
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: equally powerful emotion attributable to fewer causes or to a
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: single cause.
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof-. An emotion is only bad or hurtful, in so far as it hinders the mind
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from being able to think (IV:xxvi., IV:xxvii.); therefore, an emotion,
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whereby the mind is determined to the contemplation of several things at
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: once, is less hurtful than another equally powerful emotion, which so
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: engrosses the mind in the single contemplation of a few objects or of one,
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that it is unable to think of anything else; this was our first point.
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Again, as the mind's essence, in other words, its power (III:vii.), consists
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: solely in thought (II:xi.), the mind is less passive in respect to an
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: emotion, which causes it to think of several things at once, than in regard
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to an equally strong emotion, which keeps it engrossed in the contemplation
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of a few or of a single object: this was our second point. Lastly, this
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: emotion (III:xlviii.), in so far as it is attributable to several causes, is
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: less powerful in regard to each of them. Q.E.D.
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop.X. So long as we are not assailed by emotions contrary to
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: our nature, we have the power of arranging and associating the
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: modifications of our body according to the intellectual order.
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.- The emotions, which are contrary to our nature, that is (IV:xxx.),
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which are bad, are bad in so far as they impede the mind from understanding
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (IV:xxvii.). So long, therefore, as we are not assailed by emotions contrary
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to our nature, the mind's power, whereby it endeavours to understand things
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (IV:xxvi.), is not impeded, and therefore it is able to form clear and
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: distinct ideas and to deduce them one from another (II:xl.Note.ii. and
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: II:xlvii.Note); consequently we have in such cases the power of arranging
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and associating the modifications of the body according to the intellectual
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: order. Q.E.D.
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.- By this power of rightly arranging and associating the bodily
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: modifications we can guard ourselves from being easily affected by evil
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: emotions. For (V:vii.) a greater force is needed for controlling the
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: emotions, when they are arranged and associated according to the
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: intellectual order, than when they, are uncertain and unsettled. The best we
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: can do, therefore, so long as we do not possess a perfect knowledge of our
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: emotions, is to frame a system of right conduct, or fixed practical
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: precepts, to commit it to memory, and to apply it forthwith to the
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: particular circumstances which now and again meet us in life, so that our
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: imagination may become fully imbued therewith, and that it may be always
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ready to our hand. For instance, we have laid down among the rules of life
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (IV:xlvi., & Note), that hatred should be overcome with love or high-
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mindedness, and not required with hatred in return. Now, that this precept
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of reason may be always ready to our hand in time of need, we should often
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: think over and reflect upon the wrongs generally committed by men, and in
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: what manner and way they may be best warded off by high-mindedness: we shall
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thus associate the idea of wrong with the idea of this precept, which
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: accordingly will always be ready for use when a wrong is done to us
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (II:xviii.). If we keep also in readiness the notion of our true
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: advantage, and of the good which follows from mutual friendships, and common
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fellowships; further, if we remember that complete acquiescence is the
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: result of the right way of life (IV:lii.), and that men, no less than
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: everything else, act by the necessity of their nature: in such case I say
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the wrong, or the hatred, which commonly arises therefrom, will engross a
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: very small part of our imagination and will be easily overcome; or, if the
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: anger which springs from a grievous wrong be not overcome easily, it will
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nevertheless be overcome, though not without a spiritual conflict, far
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sooner than if we had not thus reflected on the subject beforehand. As is
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: indeed evident from V:vi.,V:vii.,V:viii. We should, in the same way, reflect
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: on courage as a means of overcoming fear; the ordinary dangers of life
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: should frequently be brought to mind and imagined, together with the means
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whereby through readiness of resource and strength of mind we can avoid and
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: overcome them. But we must note, that in arranging our thoughts and
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceptions we should always bear in mind that which is good in every
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: individual thing (IV:lxiii.Coroll. and III:lix.), in order that we may
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: always be determined to action by an emotion of pleasure. For instance, if
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a man sees that he is too keen in the pursuit of honour, let him think over
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: its right use, the end for which it should be pursued, and the means whereby
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: he may attain it. Let him not think of its misuse, and its emptiness, and
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the fickleness of mankind, and the like, whereof no man thinks except
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: through a morbidness of disposition; with thoughts like these do the
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: most ambitious most torment themselves, when they despair of gaining the
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: distinctions they hanker after, and in thus giving vent to their anger would
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fain appear wise. Wherefore it is certain that those, who cry out the
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: loudest against the misuse of honour and the vanity of the world, are those
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: who most greedily covet it. This is not peculiar to the ambitious, but is
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: common to all who are ill-used by fortune, and who are infirm in spirit.
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: For a poor man also, who is miserly, will talk incessantly of the misuse of
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: wealth and of the vices of the rich; whereby he merely torments himself, and
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: shows the world that he is intolerant, not only of his own poverty, but also
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of other people's riches. So, again, those who have been ill received by a
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: woman they love think of nothing but the inconstancy, treachery, and other
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: stock faults of the fair sex; all of which they consign to oblivion,
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: directly they are again taken into favour by their sweetheart. Thus he who
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: would govern his emotions and appetite solely by the love of freedom
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: strives, as far as he can, to gain a knowledge of the virtues and their
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: causes, and to fill his spirit with the joy which arises from the true
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: knowledge of them: he will in no wise desire to dwell on men's faults, or to
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: carp at his fellows, or to revel in a false show of freedom. Whosoever will
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: diligently observe and practise these precepts (which indeed are not
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: difficult) will verily, in a short space of time, be able, for the most
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: part, to direct his actions according to the commandments of reason.
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop.XI. In proportion as a mental image is referred to more
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: objects, so is it more frequent, or more often vivid, and occupies
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the mind more.
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.- In proportion as a mental image or an emotion is referred to more
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: objects, so are there more causes whereby it can be aroused and fostered,
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: all of which (by hypothesis) the mind contemplates simultaneously in
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: association with the given emotion; therefore the emotion is more frequent,
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or is more often in full vigour, and (V:viii.) occupies the mind more.
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Q.E.D.
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop.XII. The mental images of things are more easily
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: associated with the images referred to things which we clearly
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and distinctly understand, than with others.
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.- Things, which we clearly and distinctly understand, are either the
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: common properties of things or deductions therefrom (see definition of
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Reason, II:.xl.Note ii.), and are consequently (by the last Prop.) more
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: often aroused in us. Wherefore it may more readily happen, that we should
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: contemplate other things in conjunction with these than in conjunction with
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: something else, and consequently (II:xviii.) that the images of the said
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: things should be more often associated with the images of these than with
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the images of something else. Q.E.D.
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop. XIII. A mental image is more often vivid, in proportion
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as it is associated with a greater number of other images.
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.- In proportion as an image is associated with a greater number of
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: other images, so (II:xviii.) are there more causes whereby it can be
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: aroused. Q.E.D.
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop. XIV. The mind can bring it about, that all bodily
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: modifications or images of things may be referred to the
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: idea of God.
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.- There is no modification of the body, whereof the mind may not form
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: some clear and distinct conception (V:iv.); wherefore it can bring it about,
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop. XV. He who clearly and distinctly understands himself
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as he more understands himself and his emotions.
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: feels pleasure (III:liii.), and this pleasure is (by the last Prop.)
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: accompanied by the idea of God; therefore (Def. of the Emotions:vi.) such an
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: one loves God, and (for the same reason) so much the more in proportion as
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: he more understands himself and his emotions. Q.E.D.

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop. XVI. This love towards God must
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hold the chief place in the mind.
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.- For this love is associated with all the modifications of the body
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (V:xiv.) and is fostered by them all (V:v.); therefore (V:xi.), it must hold
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the chief place in the mind. Q.E.D.

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop. XVII. God is without passions,
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: neither is he affected by
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: any emotion of pleasure or pain.

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (II:xxxii.), that is (II:Def.iv.) adequate; and therefore (by the general
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to a greater or to a lesser perfection (I:xx.Coroll.ii.); therefore
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (by Def. of the Emotions:ii., &iii.) he is not affected by any emotion of

title: Ethics — Part 5

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consequently (Def. of the Emotions:vi., &vii.) he does not love or hate

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: anyone.

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (IV:xxxvi),and we desire that all should rejoice therein (IV:xxxvii.);

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: regard to things whereof no one can be really master.

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and especially that third kind of knowledge (II:xlvii.Note), founded on the

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or remember what is past, while the body endures.

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: endures. Yet, as there is something, notwithstanding, which is conceived by
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a certain eternal necessity through the very essence of God (last Prop.);
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.- This idea, which expresses the essence of the body under the form of
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the essence of the mind, and is necessarily eternal. Yet it is not possible
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the mind, whereby it sees and observes things, are none other than proofs.
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 5

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop. XXVII. From this third kind of
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: acquiescence. Q.E.D.

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop. XXVIII. The endeavour or desire to
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cannot arise from the first, but from the
title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 5
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop. XXIX. Whatsoever the mind understands

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 5
